title: Animated type
content:
Hello to everybody! :)  
I wonder if you can recommend me any site where  
I can find good examples of animated type.

Thanks in advance,

Laura Meseguer

 [‹ Meta Everywhere](http://web.archive.org/web/20080924093444/http:/www.typophile.com/node/31515 "Go to previous forum topic") [Adobe CS3 release ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080924093444/http:/www.typophile.com/node/31579 "Go to next forum topic")
author: laura meseguer

comments.content:
I already found a very nice list “Kinetic Type” on this site  
 [http://typophile.com/wiki/kinetic\_type](http://web.archive.org/web/20080924093444/http:/typophile.com/wiki/kinetic_type "http://typophile.com/wiki/kinetic\_type")

I’ll have a look to it!

L
Do you mean type that actually moves or the sort of type with irregular baseline placement?
HI Laura. Good to see you here. Here’s my favorite recent example, but it’s kind of silly: [Akzidenz Grotesk](http://web.archive.org/web/20080924093444/http:/www.youtube.com/watch?v=L5ol02WPaYM)

Thanks for you all. I already visited all the links.

Thanks Stephen for your welcome and the suggestion (funny one).  
Actually I’m looking for stop-motion examples, but based mostly on animated letters than in words... I want to prepare an assignment for my students, and this is why I’m collecting some examples.

Look at this site:  
 [http://nejib.uing.net](http://web.archive.org/web/20080924093444/http:/nejib.uing.net/ "http://nejib.uing.net")

Inspired on Norman MacLaren movies, which I like a lot!

laura

Get a some [Gumby DVDs](http://web.archive.org/web/20080924093444/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/sets/1168574/)! Art Clokey’s titles were as fun and animated as the episodes themselves. Here’s one: [Gumby Concerto](http://web.archive.org/web/20080924093444/http:/www.youtube.com/watch?v=LwM6i13pGqw)
